Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing NGO Communications to Understand Contestation and Collaboration with Governments Across Human Rights Issues

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human rights organizations (HR NGOs), such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and Amnesty International, use a range of strategies to improve human rights and social conditions around the world. Some strategies take the form of overt and direct criticism of states to punish and deter repression of citizens, known as "naming and shaming". Other strategies involve positive cooperation with governments to change legal and de facto protections of rights and freedoms. To date, we know little about which strategy is more effective, because systematic research on this topic has ignored direct collaboration between these organizations and states. Instead, there has been a recent explosion in the number of social science studies examining the efficacy of contentious strategies. This research will provide new insight into whether such cooperative strategies are an effective means to improve human rights and social conditions.

This project is the first to analyze the large-scale digital communications from human rights non-governmental organizations (HR NGOs) to understand the specific issues and contexts where cooperation can be successfully implemented. The researchers will demonstrate the usefulness of this approach through quantitative text analysis procedure analyzing a wide range of digitally available information (i.e. press releases, published reports, newsletters, and social media posts from multiple HR NGOs). These are an especially rich source of information as they contain both cooperative and confrontational signals to states. The research team plans to build theoretically informed models that predict 1) the issues and circumstances that provide incentives for government-HR NGO partnerships versus public criticism known as "naming and shaming," and 2) when particular HR NGO strategies ultimately lead to the desired changes in state behavior. This research has the potential to enhance the well-being of society by providing a better understanding of strategies that improve human rights performance around the world. It is also poised to make an important contribution in helping to foster collaboration between the social sciences and other STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we re-conceptualized the measurement of human rights from heterogeneous texts to better understand changes in violations over time, as well as how policies could be implemented to improve protections. For over a decade, human rights had been measured and tracked largely as an index, like GDP, where one number could describe a country and its relative protection or violation of human rights as compared to other governments. This approach became increasingly controversial as many argued that NGO engagements and reports on human rights were skewing trends to look depressing and flat, when actually behavior could be improving. Through work on our new human rights texts parser, PULSAR, and new models that can learn the taxonomic structure of general and specific aspects/issues of human rights, we began to see that this debate was ill-posed.

Human rights are plural, not singular. Therefore, we should not think about tracking a singular index, but instead re-double the energy invested in measuring the individual aspects of human rights over time. Further, we noted that human rights were not disconnected concepts but have roots in human rights laws and conceptions. This framed our next set of tasks related to measuring engagement on specific rights by different human rights groups. We needed to not only measures what rights where being judged in text with PULSAR, but also the connections between the rights. Our system successfully tracks what human rights are being judged by which agencies and how the definition of those concepts changes over time and group. 

Our group was the first to measure the implicit taxonomy of human rights aspects that are being judged in human rights texts over time, systematically from large-scale texts. We find a large and substantively important shift in the meaning of human rights itself, as measured across different human rights reporting groups (both governmental and non-governmental). Further, these shifts arose along with deepening information communication technologies, including high resolution satellite photos, camera phones, and social media usage. To support these findings and encourage more research across these areas, we have made public the Human Rights NGO reports and press releases that we have collected and the PUSLAR parser. Researchers and policy-makers can use our research as well as these resources not only to better measure and understand human rights, but also for the analysis of propaganda, disinformation, and judgments on aspects of the world more generally.
